result.title: Objective
result.description: Biodiversity (BD) conservation is integrated into the fisheries, tourism and property development sectors that operate in the archipelagos of Panama.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: -Degree of compliance of regulations for number and size of boats in LPA and Kuna Yala.

baseline.comment:
Decree Law No. 17 of July 9, 1959 \\\"by which fishing is regulated and also approves the export of fishery products in the Republic of Panama, and regulates tonnage for small-scale fisheries.
Executive Decree 124 of November 8, 1990 establishes the obligation of obtaining the permit of fishing.
There are no regulations to set number of boats only to set the size.

target.comment: At least 75% compliance.

actual.comment:
Conservation International has fiinished the technical document titled "Comprehensive Base Study for Managing Fishing Resources in the ALP." The study contains relevant information about the number of fishermen, fishing sites, the species caught and the sizes.
The study reports that the community of San Miguel (ALP) has boats that are between 16 and 22 feet long. In Esmeralda they range from 16 to 24 feet in overall length. There are no regulations that set boat dimensions. The only thing considered for classifying boats is the tonnage.
In GunaYala, they generally use sail boats or dugouts. There are no regulations defined for the dimensions. More than 10 years of information exists about boats related to lobster fishing.
The mid-term evaluation considered removing this indicator because it disorients the PIU.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Percentage of boats using buoys to reduce coral damage in LPA and Kuna Yala.

baseline.comment:
No buoys in LPA and only a few in Kuna Yala with low % of use.
Actually there are 18 buoys that were located in the LPA through a strategic alliance between STRI/IC and Ancon and they were placed in the year 2011.
In the case de of Guna Yala there is no information

target.comment: 80% or more compliance of boats using buoys.

actual.comment:
The PIU coordinated monitoring with the ARAP Division of Inspection, Oversight, and Control to verify the use of buoys. However, the reports sent do not show any results for boats and/or yachts anchored at the established buoys.
GunaYala has buoys to protect biodiversity, located at Islas Tigre, Narganá, Agwanusadub, and Niadub.
The mid-term evaluation considered eliminating this indicator because there is no buoy manager. No maintenance is given to them. The location was not assessed.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of turtle nesting beaches and their quality as habitat for turtles across 33,000 hectares in LAP and 218,000 ha in Kuna Yala

baseline.comment:
37 beaches in LPA good habitat for turtles. To be determined for Kuna Yala.
For Guna Yala Archipelago turtle nesting beaches were identified in the document called Action Plan for the Protection of the Caribbean Sea Turtle.

target.comment: 37 beaches in LPA good habitat for turtles.

actual.comment:
ARAP and international organizations carry out the process to mark sea turtles in the ALP.
ARAP, with the support of its counterpart and of the Ministry of the Environment participates in the First Hawksbill Turtle Project Campaign to determine the presence and abundance of the Hawksbill Turtle (Eretmochelysimbricata) in the Coiba National Park.
Inspection and oversight actions were carried out by ARAP to monitor the hectares of nesting beaches for sea turtles in the ALP. This year there were no changes in the established beach areas.
The mid-term evaluation considered eliminating this indicator because it is part of the Las Perlas management plan.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Reduction in hectares of forest and mangrove deforested by residential projects in LPA.

baseline.comment: 1400 ha of mangrove remaining and annual deforestation rate of 1% (70% forest cover in 2000).

target.comment: Net deforestatrion rates zero due to residential projects.

actual.comment:
ARAP does monitoring inspections to check the mangrove cutting in the ALP. ARAP is waiting for official information from UNN-REDD to establish whether the forest and mangrove coverage in the ALP has been deforested or not.
The change in management by the new Minister of the Environment implied reviewing all the actions in the methodology and the results. Therefore, there are still no official figures. The project has held meetings with the project managers.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Lobster harvesting respects minimum catch size within the 136,000 ha of LPA marinescape.

baseline.comment: All sizes caught.

target.comment: All catch size above minimum size.

actual.comment:
There is a draft of the decree on zoning, fishing, and marketing lobster in the jurisdictional areas in the Republic of Panama.
ARAP spent 9 months without a General Manager, which stopped it from taking the budget to the Executive area.
The project will provide continuity for the new recently designated authorities.
(February 2014) for the proposal to be raised to the level of an Executive Decree and be sanctioned.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Increase in financial contributions from tourism, property development and fishing sectors in collaborative conservation management models in Bocas, Kuna Yala, LPA and Coiba archipelagos.

baseline.comment: In 2009 property developers who are members of CRSIP spent $60,000 in the LPA on activities related to improving waste management, environmental education and other activities desgned to reduce negative impacts on biodiversity. A further $60,000 was generated in 2008 from tourism for Kuna Yala government, but this was not invested in conservation management. Tourism in Coiba (ANAM lodge) and in Bocas (to e.g. BSTA memebership) generated an undetermined though likely low amount from tourism, some of which has been invested in conservation management. The amounts generated are well below the estimated costs of managing the sector ´s activities sustainably (Threshold of Sustainability). There are currently no other flows of finance from these sectors to conservation.

target.comment: Financial contributions cover 50% of threshold of sustainability (covered by annual license fees, taxes, etc).

actual.comment:
The project set up a strategic alliance with CI as support to establish the mechanisms to collect taxes or municipal fees that may be applied to promote and increase the financial contributions to conserve the ALP's biodiversity.
A specialist (Environmental Economist) was hired. The specialist held a workshop to raise awareness for the project's partners about financial mechanisms that may be implemented to protect the biodiversity in the ALP. Some 20 partners participated in the event
As a result of this workshop, some financial mechanisms identified in the PRODOC were not considered as being a priority for execution in the initial phase, such as the Habitat Banking case. It should be emphasized that short-term fees and rates were established.
There is a strategic alliance to establish the mechanisms to collect taxes or municipal fees that may be applied to promote and increase the financial contributions to conserve the ALP's biodiversity.

target.comment: At least 75% compliance

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Cost- effective market-based instruments and improved investment opportunities for biodiversity friendly tourism and fisheries developed and promoted in the Archipelago of Las Perlas (LPA)

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: There are currently products of ecotourism in the LPA directed to whale-watching, beach tourism and snorkel offered by a company (Coral Dreams)

baseline.comment: None

target.comment: 10 products.

actual.comment:
In the ALP, three tourism products are operating.
1. Cetaceans were sighted, which is carried out by the Whale Watching company in conjunction with the Hotel The Point. They are working to raise awareness and also educate the boat people on good practices for whale watching.
The packages they offer includes a 3-hour tour from Contadura: They work with a local boat owner, normally from Saboga, and with a Panamanian guide, foreigners, and biologists who guide the tour. They have prepared an educational guide that they use on the tours to educate and raise the awareness of tourists about the importance of conserving whales. The price is $50.
A full one-day tour from Contadora: The tour departs from Contadora on a catamaran sailboat and lasts a full day. It also includes food. There is a biologist and they also work with a guide. The price is $150. Tour from Panama City. The tour departs in a yacht from Panama City and does not include food. The price is $200. The tour stops for lunch at one of the restaurants in Contadora.
2. The Beach Tourism project is associated with hotels and tour operators. This project has consolidated with the two ferry lines (the "Las Perlas Sea" ferry) that visit most of the islands in the ALP and OFFER BEACH TOURS TO THE TOURISTS.
3. Snorkeling: Associated with various tour operators, where the Coral Dreams stands out, snorkeling packages are offered to tourists that visit Contadora Island.
4. The project will develop actions to strengthen these tourism products and other products that are currently being consolidated that currently occur sporadically in the ALP. The actions are focused on supporting organized entrepreneurs with the support of the ALP to train staff and provide technical guidance for the products.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of buyers of certified ecotourism and sustainable tourism products.

baseline.comment: None

target.comment: 10 certified business (with others in process) having made 1,000 sales in total to Panama based tour operators as well as international companies.

actual.comment:
The project hired a specialist in Good Sustainable Tourism Practices to train the company and tour operators in the ALP and the Bocas del Toro Archipelago (Isla Colón and Isla Carenero).
Training was provided to 11 companies in the Las Perlas Archipelago; and to 18 companies in the Bocas del Toro Archipelago (Isla Colón, Carenero, Bastimentos) on Good Sustainable Tourism Practices. The training session included the following contents: Sustainable design, the use of potable water, use of electricity, environmental interpretation, handling the impact by visitors, and establishing financial mechanisms to protect biodiversity.
There is a strategic plan to implement the environmental credits in the La Perlas and Bocas del Toro (Isla Carenero, Bastimentos, and Isla Colón) archipelagos.
Formal work was done with the ALP through the tourism quality and culture department to coordinate the development of outstanding tasks pertaining to future certifications for good practices.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Voluntary standards adopted by cruise ship operators and residential developers in LPA.

baseline.comment: None

target.comment:
- All cruise ships operating in LPA have adopted the standards.
- 50% of residential developments have adopted voluntary standards.

actual.comment:
The PIU sent the project partners (ARAP, ATP, ANAM) the proposed regulations to protect biodiversity linked to real estate development to disclose the regulations and to later provide a joint analysis to have them approved.
Coordination was set up with MIVIOT around the land zoning regulations on the coasts and the insular territory that was advanced by the territorial research division.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: % of local community enterprises that have received certification in best practices for sustainable tourism in LPA

target.comment: 50% of local communities businesses (handicraft, boat tours, hostelsm guides, etc)

actual.comment: The value chain integration study identified the tourism businesses or companies with a community base that may be developed in Las Perlas Archipelago. These tourism businesses are: Cultural Show, Environmental Education through Children's Puppetry, Fruit Processing and Tourist Circuits to Las Perlas Archipelago. For each community tourism business identified in the ALP, its chain of value is structured and the tourism business is descrie. Students in the tourism career program were trained in San Miguel Cabecera and Pedro Gonzales so they would learn the theoretic bases for tourism planning, view practical examples of resources, attractions, and tourism products from other tourist destinations in the world whose characteristics are similar to the ALP's characteristics. The different types of jobs in tourism and community tourism companies that may be created to satisfy the domestic and international demand for tourism were also shown. There is a strategic plan to promote and market the tourist products.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: % of fishing vessels working under a sustainable management scheme in LPA.

actual.comment:
The Project hired a fishing extension worker to implement co-management systems in Las Perlas Archipelago.
Studies are underway to identify the potential areas to implement the co-management projects in the ALP. The result is that the Casaya community will be the initial implementation site.
The study results were presented to the key stakeholders (fishermen) and project partners. Two co-management projects were defined: oysters and shrimp.
The shrimp fattening project in floating cages has been installed in the community of Casaya. A total of 14,000 post-larva have been seeded. Fifteen artisanal fishermen in the ALP participated. The idea is to support fishermen to improve their economic and social life.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Annual amount of credits placed in small and medium community enterprises to develop BD-friendly businesses.

baseline.comment: None

target.comment: $200,000 in small grants and $500,000 in bank credits.

actual.comment:
The Project has already identified the tourism and fishing businesses in the ALP. However, no credits have been given yet since they must be structured to be submitted for consideration for the PPD program.
The mid-term evaluation considered removing this indicator.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Improved sectoral policies and regulations that enable mainstreaming BD conservation into the tourism, fisheries and property development operations in the Archipelagos of Panama.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Enactment of specific legislation for tourism and property development in islands to reduce impacts on biodiversity.

baseline.comment:
None.
There is the law N º 2 of January 7, 2006, that regulates concessions for tourism investment and the alienation of island territory for purposes of its tourist exploitation and teaches other provisions.
Decreto Ejecutivo No. 85 de 19 de Julio de 2006 â€œQue reglamenta la ley n º 2 de 7 de enero de 2006, que regula las concesiones para la inversiÃ³n turÃ­stica y la enajenaciÃ³n del territorio insular para fines de su aprovechamiento turÃ­stico y dicta otras disposiciones.
LEY 80 de 8 de noviembre de 2012, G.O. 27159-A â€œQue dicta normas de incentivos para el fomento de la actividad turÃ­stica en PanamÃ¡â€?

target.comment: Norm implemented.

actual.comment:
The project partners (ARAP, ATP, ANAM) were sent the Regulations for Protecting Biodiversity Linked to Tourism and Real Estate Development in Las Perlas Archipelago, the District of Balboa, the Province of Panama.
Coordination was set up with MIVIOT around the land zoning regulations on the coasts and the insular territory that was advanced by the territorial research division.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Enactment of new regulations for fisheries to regulate impacts on biodiversity

baseline.comment:
- None for sport fishing
- Current regulation for spiny lobster leaves gaps for adequate management.
- Se cuenta con el Plan de Manejo para la langosta del Caribe.
-There is the resolution No.2 of February 16, 2012 \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\"which prohibits the sale and marketing of species obtained from sport fishingâ€?.

target.comment: Both regulations implemented.

actual.comment:
The PIU and ARAP worked jointly on the proposal that establishes the measures for zoning, management, and sustainable use of lobster in the Republic of Panama's jurisdictional waters. It was agreed to by the fishermen and reviewed by the ARAP's legal advisor.
It was not promulgated since the ARAP had no manager for a period of 9 months. This is the key person for the proposed regulation to be upheld by the Executive Branch and sanctioned.
As for sport fishing, the past administration was not interested in zoning it. The project will continue to make an effort for this new administration to allow the regulations to be prepared

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Enactment of specific regulations on marinas, boating, anchoring and access to islands.

baseline.comment: The Republic of Panama has the Law N ° 56 of August 6, 2008 â€œGeneral Law of Panama Portsâ€?

target.comment: Norm implemented.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: -EIA guidelines include more stringent standards to measure impacts on biodiversity.

baseline.comment: Existing EIA guidelines.

target.comment: New guidelines enforced.

actual.comment:
The last ANAM administration was not interested in adopting guidelines that contained stricter standards for the projects in the coastal marine areas.
They thought that they contained standards that were too difficult to meet. ARAP continues using them to do the evaluations for the environmental impact studies for the marine coastal areas.
The project will make an effort with the new Minister of the Environment to make the pertinent adjustments and figure out whether these standards will be adopted or not.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: -Habitat banking system established as a way to improve the protection of forests and other ecosystems.

baseline.comment: None.

target.comment: 50% of compliance with zoning regulations involves habitat banking or similar scheme.

actual.comment:
As a result of the strategic alliance with Conservation International (CI). A specialist (Environmental Economist) was able to be hired to do an analysis of the ALP's current situation and the possibility of implementing financial mechanisms to protect biodiversity.
There was a workshop held to let the project partners (ARAP, ATP, ANAM, CI and the UNDP representatives) hear about the different types of financial mechanisms in existence to protect biodiversity. The workshop was attended by 20 partners.
Seventeen (17) financial mechanisms were analyzed that may be implemented in the ALP. Short-term financial mechanisms were prioritized in an expert workshop that are applicable to the ALP such as fees charged to ferries, hotels, restaurants, and tour operators.
There is a long-term financial mechanism strategic plan (for five years).
The mid-term evaluation report considered removing this indicator and coordinating with ANAM about the contents of the strategic plan for financial mechanisms to protect biodiversity.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Local governance for planning, capacity building and policy enforcement strengthened in LPA pilot area.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: -ARAP and ANAM have decentralized operation, presence and expertise in the archipelagos.

baseline.comment: No local offices of ARAP or ANAM in LPA.

target.comment: ANAM and ARAP have fisheries and tourism experts as permanent staff in LPA offices.

actual.comment: The PIU has provided the resumes again to ARAP to hire a secretary and inspector for the ALP. Appointments are waiting to be announced.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: -Budget expenditure by municipality and planning and supervising tourism, fishing and property development activities.

baseline.comment:
US$0.00
The contribution of the municipality to the fishing sector during the years 2012 and 2013 tilt around B/.7, 972 in concept of boat, motor outboard and fuel.
La ATP elaborÃ³ el plan maestro de turismo 2007-2020 como una herramienta de planificaciÃ³n turÃ­stica que incluye el ALP como zona de desarrollo turistico

target.comment: 100% of those project needs which are the responsibility of municipality.

actual.comment: ARAP carried out oversight and control actions for the 2014 period; however, they were few due to the lack of an ARAP manager. The overall amount spent on inspections has not been made compatible.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: -Frequency of interactions between ARAP, ANAM, municipality and fishermen (inspections in open sea and landing sites, information and consultation meetings).

baseline.comment: No interactions.

target.comment: At least once every week.

actual.comment:
There were 13 instances of interaction between ANAM, ARAP and ATP related to the following activities:
Workshop on financial mechanisms to protect biodiversity in the ALP. Twenty (20) partners (ARAP, ATP, ANAM, and CI) participated in the project.
Workshop on Isla Contadora to present the results of the tourist survey and also to present possible tourism businesses that may be added to the ALP value chain. Fourteen (14) tourism operators from the ALP participated.
A workshop was held in San Miguel targeting the career program in tourism and a group of artisans about identifying resources, activities, and tourism jobs in the ALP. Eighteen (18) people participated.
A workshop was held in Pedro González targeting the career program in tourism about identifying resources, activitites, and tourism jobs in the ALP. Thirteen (13) people participated.
A workshop was held in San Miguel to show the students in the career program the results of the market study carried out on Isla Contadora, approve the value chain, and make certain pledges related to upcoming training sessions and future projects. Thirteen (13) people participated.
Meeting with ARAP in the community of San Miguel to coordinate actions about fishing zoning, research, and inspection and oversight. Five (5) ARAP employees participated.
The project partners (ARAP, ATP, ANAM) and key stakeholders in the ALP were presented the studies carried out to establish the co-management projects. A total of fourteen (14) people participated.
Meeting with artisanal fishermen in San Miguel to present the co-management projects. Training sessions were held in Casaya to install and organize the co-management projects in the ALP. A total of 15 fishermen participated.
The results of the consulting work on the Value Chain Integration done in San Miguel were presented to the ALP'S partners and key stakeholders. A total of thirty-five (35) people participated.
A training session was held on Isla Contadora about good sustainable tourism practices. Ten (10) key stakeholders in the ALP tied to tourism participated.
Training was held on Isla Colón, the Bocas del Toro Archipelago, on good sustainable tourism practices. Fifteen (15) key stakeholders tied to tourism participated.
Training was held in GunaYala on tourism business administration, customer service, tour guides, and marketing tourism services. Twenty-five (25) key stakeholders tied to tourism participated.
A workshop was held in the area of the marine reserve in Las Perlas Archipelago to present the zoning proposals and alternate regulations. A total of fifteen (15) project partners participated.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: -Implementation of a monitoring and evaluation system to monitor indicators of key threats (overfishing, turtle nesting, visitation, etc.) in LPA.

baseline.comment: No monitoring system in place.

target.comment: Monitoring system in implementation.

actual.comment:
There is a data platform available containing all the information on fishing, tourism and real estate development in the ALP.
An ARAP employee was trained to manage the spatial data infrastructure platform and the procedures manual was relinquished.
The project has considered doing a study to figure out which system would make it possible to monitor threats to biodiversity.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: -Annual amount of funds mobilized by Payment for Environmental Services (PES) system and green taxes for the protection of forests and marine ecosystems in LPA.

baseline.comment:
- No PES system is in place
- Symbolic Water fee is being charged by Isla del Rey.

target.comment:
- PES system operating and secured for long term.
- 50% of financial needs of existing conservation areas in LPA year are covered with funds generated by PES schemes.

actual.comment:
As a result of the strategic alliance with Conservation International (CI). A specialist (Environmental Economist) was able to be hired to do an analysis of the ALP's current situation and the possibility of implementing financial mechanisms to protect biodiversity, including the PSA.
There was a workshop held to let the project partners (ARAP, ATP, ANAM, CI) hear about the different types of financial mechanisms in existence to protect biodiversity. The workshop was attended by 20 partners.
Seventeen (17) financial mechanisms were analyzed that may be implemented in the ALP. Short-term financial mechanisms were prioritized in an expert workshop that are applicable to the ALP. For short-term implementation, fees charged to ferries, hotels, restaurants, and tour operators were feasible. The PSA was rated to be viable for implementation in the medium term.
There is a long-term financial mechanism strategic plan (for five years).
The PIU will coordinate with the Ministry of the Environment about whether it is possible to have the financial mechanism strategic plan applied to the ALP.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: -% of property development areas that comply with zoning regulations in LPA

baseline.comment:
0% because there are no zoning regulations in place.
Ley 6 de 1 de febrero de 2006, G.O. 25,478 â€œQue reglamenta el ordenamiento territorial para el desarrollo urbano y dicta otras disposicionesâ€?.
Decreto ejecutivo No. 23 de 16 de mayo de 2007, G.O. 25794 â€œPor el cual se reglamenta la Ley 6 de 1 de febrero de 2006 Que reglamenta el ordenamiento territorial para el desarrollo urbano y dicta otras disposicionesâ€?
ResoluciÃ³n N º 4-2009 de 20 de enero de 2009, G.O. 26221â€œPor la cual se establece el procedimiento y los requisitos para la tramitaciÃ³n de solicitudes relacionadas con el ordenamiento territorial para el desarrollo urbanoâ€?

target.comment: 100% comply with zoning regulations.

actual.comment: Since the ARAP did not have a manager formally appointed for 9 months, the paperwork with the MIVIOT could not be done to verify the development areas and whether they met the existing zoning regulations.

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: BD friendly tourism, fisheries and property development practices replicated in PanamaÂ´s remaining three archipelagos.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: -Revenues collected by Kuna Yala from visitation that are allocated to BD conservation activities.

baseline.comment: Around US$60K generated but zero allocated to BD.

target.comment: Optimum needs identified and revenue generation mechanisms identified.

actual.comment: Conversations were held with the Secretary of Tourism in the General Guna Congress and so far the information has not been able to be provided. So far, this information is not available. The ATP was checked for the tourism planning address but there is no information.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: -Voluntary standards adopted by cruise ships operators in Panama archipelagos.

baseline.comment: None

target.comment: All cruise ships operating in Panama have adopted the standards.

actual.comment: The project has a coordination meeting outstanding with the new authorities of the PANAMA Maritime Authority to jointly analyze the possibility of setting up new initiatives

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: -% of tourism developments in Bocas, Kuna Yala, Coiba and LPA that comply with international standards for sustainable tourism.

baseline.comment: 0% certified enterprises at the moment.

actual.comment:
The project hired a specialist in Sustainable Tourism Best Practices to train the company and tour operators in the ALP and the Bocas del Toro Archipelago (Isla Colón and Isla Carenero).
Training was provided to 11 companies in the Las Perlas Archipelago and to 18 companies in the Bocas del Toro Archipelago (Isla Colón, Carenero, Bastimentos) on Sustainable Tourism Best Practices. The training session included the following contents: Sustainable design, the use of potable water, use of electricity, environmental interpretation, handling the impact by visitors, establishing financial mechanisms to protect biodiversity.
There is a strategic plan to implement environmental credits in the La Perlas and Bocas del Toro (Isla Carenero, Bastimentos, and Isla Colón) archipelagos. The same thing is true for the TDR to hire the specialist to implement the strategic plan.
In Guna Yala, 25 stakeholders linked to tourism were trained on managing tourism businesses, customer service, tour guides and marketing tourism services.
In the training session, community tourism development projects were identified that, with the joint direction of the 6 towns, are expected to be able to be developed.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: -% of tourist expenditure that is allocated to conservation

baseline.comment: Less than 2% in LPA, Bocas and Kuna Yala (to verify).

actual.comment:
The project did a study in the ALP to draw a profile of tourists coming to the ALP, to find out what tourism activities they are engaged in, and to identify their lodging preferences.
Some 70% of the tourists surveyed spent two days on Isla Contadora. On a daily basis, the tourists spent, in different ranges: 23% spent between US $51 and $100; 20% spent between $100 and $150; and 20% spent between $200 and $300.

result.title: Objective
result.description: The discovery of nature-based products for the pharmaceutical and agrochemical industries and benefit sharing to promote the sustainable use of genetic resources in the Protected Areas System of Panama

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of lead compounds for agrochemical and pharmaceutical uses discovered during the project period

target.comment: 1 lead compound

actual.comment: Bioprospecting required for identification of promising compounds is been carried out. Research to identify the lead compound is taking place.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Discovering active compounds for pharmaceutical and agrochemical uses from terrestrial and marine organisms in protected areas and improvement of the capacities of ANAM for their monitoring

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of highly active compounds for agrochemical and pharmaceutical uses discovered during the project period

target.comment: 10 highly active compounds

actual.comment: Advances in this area include publications by researchers such as Dr. Gerwich, Helen McField, Dr. Linintong, and Dr. Balunas. There is a strong probability of eight compounds entering this group. New tests are being conducted with the help of private partners associated with the project. The pharmaceutical industry has an interest in one of compounds in this group.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of extracts tested in cancer, tropical disease and agrochemical bioassays by the Panama ICBG and by private sector partners during the project period

target.comment: 2,500 extracts

actual.comment: 2,059 samples tested STRI (2012- Mar. 2014); 9,134 samples tested INDICASAT (2012- Jan. 2014); 1,102 samples tested INDICASAT (April- Sept. 2014); 424 samples tested STRI (April-July 2014); testing on 29 samples reported at local level STRI (August-October 2014); 25 samples tested STRI (15 April 2015); 21 samples tested STRI (7 July 2015); 443 (October-December 2014) and 517 bioassays by INDICASAT AIP (January-March 2015), for a total 13,754 tests reported.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of active compounds purified and their structures are elucidated during the project period

target.comment: 50 active compounds

actual.comment: To date 102 active compounds are being worked on. More tests and trials are required. The trend is for 5% of the overall total to be active. Evaluation of effectiveness and activity could reduce the quantity of active compounds. Work on 11 of these is taking place in Panama at UP-STRI and INDICASAT AIP labs (most are still in the purification and elucidation process).

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Existence of guidance for the monitoring of bioprospecting processes

baseline.comment: No formalized guidance currently available

target.comment: 1 guidance document produced on monitoring of bioprospecting processes

actual.comment: A list of guidelines for monitoring bioprospecting processes is being prepared jointly, based on the different experiences of the project’s stakeholders. In August actors will schedule a work meeting to define this output.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Adequacy of baseline agreements in relation to results of project developments and the biodiscovery process

baseline.comment: ANAM is satisfied with agreements

target.comment: ANAM is satisfied with agreements

actual.comment: The investigation process cannot ensure the development of specific outputs for this outcome yet. However, progress is reported on two very promising compounds that could move to a phase of clinical trials due a industrial interest (reports clarifying the situation are expected in August from the U.S. university partners who report through STRI). The legal framework backing the project’s development is still in force between STRI and MiAmbiente (ANAM).

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Transfer of technology and practices to facilitate the discovery of active compounds and the sustainable use of biodiversity

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Levels of installed capacities for collection, culture and long-term storage of microbes.

baseline.comment: Existing facilities at STRI, INDICASAT and the University of Panama are limited, with microbes being stored at room temperature

target.comment: Microbial bank and culturing facilities installed in a Panamanian institution

actual.comment: Verification and preparation of replications underway for the last 500 strains of endophytic fungi collected by STRI and partners. The first experiments are being made on freezing so that strains can then be stored at - 80°C. With the University of Arizona’s Dr. Betzy Arnold, information will be organized in electronic form on samples to make up the culture collection. As part of future sustainability, operational costs of conserving and maintaining the collection are reviewed. Based on Panamanian experience, the estimated cost of preserving each collection is USD 140,000 ($21,241.60 for culture medium; $21,918.00 for technician salaries, $63,860 for materials and reagents, and the rest for equipment upgrades and maintenance). Replications at ambient temperature and methods of preservation through cooling are successful thus far. Groups of microorganisms that can be stored at ambient temperatures and the conditions required have been identified.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Benefits shared with national parks and the Panamanian population

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of trails in Coiba National Park

actual.comment: Based on what has been analyzed and reviewed together with ANAM (now Ministry of the Environment) between August and December of 2014, trail tending strategy is being changed for La Santa Cruz Trail with the May 2015 finalization of rehabilitation through contract STRI 15-PO-341-0000318076 with Fundación Caminando Panamá. The length of the trail is 4.67 km and width is from 0.70 to 1 m. Fundación Caminando Panamá reports that it has not made any profit from this service. Overall the trail has three interpretive panels, confirmation and orientation markers, four rustic bridges and four signposts. Activities in replanting as seen with MiAmbiente have been reported, along with corridor clearing and drainage, improvements to drainage, definition of steps, and other activities. Lessons learned and other information collected through project implementation partners (for Los Monos and La Santa Cruz trails) provided to the ECOTUR-AP project as part of a synergy process, since more resources are needed than those available to tend a second trail (Los Monos), as well as a handbook with instructions on trail conservation and maintenance.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Numbers of species collected from Coiba National Park included in ICBG collection database

baseline.comment: 2,000 species in 2008-2010 period

target.comment: 500 additional species

actual.comment: The most current information has been compiled on the taxonomy of organisms collected by ICBG (plants, endophytic fungi, cyanobacteria, bacteria and tunicates). This information has been delivered to MiAmbiente. Work remains in classification of microorganisms by ICBG collaborator Dr. Betsy Arnold, University of Arizona, and Drs. Bill Gerwick, Roger Linington and Kevin Tidgewell, as well as support from the Missouri Botanical Garden.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Increase in awareness among the Panamanian population on the sustainable uses of biodiversity of Coiba.

baseline.comment: 230 people

target.comment: 460 people

actual.comment: Review of ANAM (MiAmbiente) survey information, which is not considered representative, and reformulation has been promoted. Based on a review of the visitor list kept by park guards and statistical reviews, a population has been identified of 230 local people with high-frequency visitation and constant contact with national and international visitors and tourists located in the national park’s buffer zones and areas of influence where attention has centered most.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Capacities among Panamanian scientists in relation to biodiscovery

baseline.comment: 143 scientists have been trained to date

target.comment:
20 additional young Panamanian scientists have been trained in biodiscovery
4 additional Panamanian scientists have been trained in foreign laboratories on biodiscovery techniques

actual.comment: To date one (1) Panamanian (H. Ortega) scientist has been trained abroad (Brazil), 11 Panamanian scientists (Masters level) are being trained in the use and basic maintenance of research equipment for applying chemical and analytical techniques in national laboratories and 31 graduating Panamanian students and/or with advanced degrees are being training in different specialties in national Panamanian laboratories. A Panamanian scientist and botanical expert (R. Flores) has been trained at the Missouri Botanical Garden and is now in the process of publishing a parallel investigation with significant findings for Panama’s protected areas.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Level of knowledge in Panamanian legislature of the potential benefits for the country of prompt ratification of the Nagoya Protocol

baseline.comment: No legislators are aware of the benefits and intend to support the ratification of the Nagoya Protocol

target.comment: 9 legislators are aware of the benefits and intend to support the ratification of the Nagoya Protocol

actual.comment: The Nagoya Protocol is part of national law. The institutions’ technical capacities in review and analysis of legislation on ABS are being strengthened, with the purpose of improving it, with particular interest in Executive Decree N°25 of 29 April 2009. Recommendations in this area were made based on project sub-outputs supporting formulation of the law creating the Ministry of Environment (Mi Ambiente), and which helped shape three of its articles.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Capacity regarding bioprospecting processes in ANAM

baseline.comment: No staff members have in-depth knowledge of bioprospecting processes in ANAM

target.comment: 3 ANAM staff members trained in different stages of bioprospecting processes

actual.comment: Of the 15 ANAM (now MiAmbiente) officials who received training at the first capacity-raising sessions, six remain and 2 new ones have been added (all members of the Department of Protected Areas and Wildlife). Topics have included contracts, negotiations, risks, stakeholders, scenarios, and processes related with Access to Genetic/Biological Resources and Traditional Knowledge. Dynamics have included exchanges with specialists in Costa Rica, Colombia, Spain, Panama and two GEF consultants assigned to the Nagoya Protocol global project. Exchanges are being prepared with homologous GEF projects in Costa Rica, and Colombia, InBio (Costa Rica) and projects in Sao Paulo, Brazil, along with a new exchange in the region through a trip by staff member Alexander Montero planned for August.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Level of capacity for negotiation of ABS agreements in ANAM

baseline.comment: 0 ANAM staff members with in-depth familiarity with processes of ABS negotiation

target.comment: 2 ANAM staff members trained in negotiation of ABS agreements

actual.comment: New needs in conceptual training have been identified and are being examined. Training in negotiation and contracts has begun but is not yet finalized. Six MiAmbiente staff members (technicians) are participating in this process. The project will probably not be able to contribute all of the knowledge instruments required in the Panamanian situation with respect to negotiation and contracts topics. Drs. Jorge Cabrera and Alejandro Lago C., among others, have been facilitators in this area, taking advantage of synergies with GEF projects and the United Nations System.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Handbooks on ABS for ANAM and genetic resource users are available

target.comment: Two procedures handbooks on ABS have been produced for ANAM and users (including proposals for framework contracts and formats for obtaining prior informed consent)

actual.comment: A document has been prepared with observations, proposals and information on Access to Genetic Resources in Panama. Drafting has begun of a handbook for users of genetic resources in Panama focusing on two vital areas: guides on access for users of genetic resources, and references for authorities. Topics for raising capacity in ABS have been reformulated in agreement with MiAmbiente focal points to improve the handbook’s content taking Panama’s situations into account. Data sheets on identified users and their needs have been put together as part of the handbook, and services in access to genetic and biological resources and traditional knowledge in Panama have been reviewed. A draft is anticipated for review in September 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Existence of methodology for determining rates for permits for access to genetic resources

baseline.comment: Executive Decree 25 of April 2009 on ABS

target.comment: Methodology has been defined for determining rates for permits for access to genetic resources

actual.comment: This work depends on progress in the development of the comprehensive manual, knowledge of negotiation topics and progress in research processes during bioprospecting. The project has not reached the level of progress to attain this goal. It is expected to achieve this goal by September 2015.
